page.title: 16LANDSCAPE IN NETHERBURY
page.content: This area is entirely rural, the largest area of buildings being that of Beaminster, dominated by the fine church tower with many pinnacles. The villages of Stoke Abbott and Netherbury nestle in the deep lanes, each having a church with a tower, the latter much hidden by scaffolding for the repair of stonework and regilding of the clock. The buildings all over the area are mostly of mellow stone, often Ham stone, many with thatched roofs,with some less traditional bungalows of recent date, the whole set in soft green valleys with small rounded hills, quiet streams and many trees, woods and copses. Important architectural features could be Strode Manor House, of about 1830, with a garden featuring small hedged "rooms" and Parnham House, a Tudor mansion, John Makepeace's School of Woodcrafts.
